awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The research focus is to understand the mechanisms underlying predator-prey dynamics in natural systems. Prey make behavioral decisions to decrease their chances of getting eaten, but the circumstances that elicit particular anti-predator responses are still poorly understood. As the choice of prey behavior can have cascading impacts on ecosystem dynamics, much work has been attempted to define how prey make these decisions. However, many of these models fail to predict observed anti-predator strategies in nature. The fellow will develop a new predator-prey framework, incorporating a rarely-explored dimension of complex communities. How predators modify their activity in response to competitors may substantially alter the risk prey ultimately experience. The fellow will study behavior of mammalian herbivores in ecosystems throughout Africa, using extensive networks of camera-traps to capture prey behavioral strategies under different predation regimes. To accomplish these aims, the fellow will work extensively with local scientists and students, providing valuable training to African K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students, in addition to running capacity building workshops with government and non-governmental agencies. The fellow will develop teaching tools and citizen science programs to introduce the general public in the US and abroad to key concepts in ecology and conservation.

This research will quantify non-additive effects of multiple predators on overall predation risk by examining how prey mitigate combined risk at multiple spatial and temporal scales. The fellow test (I) whether predator-predator interactions affect how aggregate predation risk is structured spatiotemporally across a landscape, and (II) explore whether these synergies are modulated by functional traits of the prey or the environment by (III) developing novel statistical approaches for using camera-trap data. This framework will be parameterized using data from intact systems and tested to see whether removing hypothesized linkages between different predators predicts prey behavior in degraded systems where portions of the predator guild are extinct. The fellow will be working in multiple African countries during the course of this research and will expend significant effort training students locally and globally. She will also work to increase the participation of diverse groups in STEM by developing citizen science and online educational tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The fear of predation is a driving force shaping prey behavior, but current theoretical anti-predator paradigms have had limited success predicting prey behavior in nature. During my fellowship, I investigated how largely unexplored dynamics in complex natural communities, including spatiotemporal patterns of predator behavior and carnivore trait diversity in multi-predator systems, shape predator-prey dynamics. Working in intact (i.e., complete predator guild) and recovering (i.e., lacking >1 member of the historic predator guild) African large mammal systems, I developed mechanistic frameworks that allow us to better understand the complex effects of predators on prey.

Intellectual merits: Working with partners in the USA, Tanzania, and Mozambique, I employed an integrative approach involving empirical and experimental techniques to explore strategies prey use to proactively and reactively mitigate risk. I quantified variation in predation risk through space and time and captured prey responses at multiple spatiotemporal scales to derive total predator-mediated behavioral effects. To do so, I used unprecedented long-term camera trap programs, created bespoke wildlife monitoring devices, and compiled historic records. I then modelled prey decision-making based on the functional traits of predators and prey and characteristics of the environment. This work represents a major step forward in predator-prey ecology by examining communities as a whole and deriving overarching ecological principles by comparing across systems. From this fellowship, I have produced numerous papers redefining predator-prey theory, testing this theory in natural systems, and reviewing predator-prey interactions across diverse contexts.

An active question in these systems is how to reintroduce predators in a way that enhances ecosystem recovery. Information on prey behavior derived during this fellowship will guide future conservation decisions. In addition, I established permanent wildlife monitoring infrastructure that enables managers to evaluate the outcomes of on-going conservation efforts. Lastly, I made cutting edge advances in camera trap technology, designing “smart” (AI-enabled) and reactive (performing actions upon detecting target species) camera trap camera traps that allow researchers and practitioners to study wildlife in innovative new ways.

Broader impacts: In addition to completing my research objectives, this grant allowed me to engage in outreach initiatives aimed at broadening the participation of under-represented groups in STEM at local and global scales.

To strengthen local scientific capacity in Africa, I developed two workshops for Mozambican MSc students that taught a wide variety of field research and analytical skills. One of these courses was specifically for early career women in conservation. Similarly, I created two technical skills-building courses for early career East African women in conservation which were conducted in Tanzania and Kenya. I also ran “hack-a-thons” to train Kenyan computer science students how to apply AI to solve conservation challenges. I mentored two African graduate students and have helped them publish their research and find jobs in the conservation field. In addition, I trained three Mozambican and Tanzanian field assistants (one woman), two of whom have gone on to complete undergraduate and graduate degrees. Lastly, I created scientific infrastructure (camera trap grids) that have been transferred into the stewardship of our local collaborators to facilitate future research and conservation efforts.

To educate audiences on a global scale, I have created freely available course material for college students, middle school students, and the public on fundamental principles in ecology and conservation. During this fellowship, I performed online and in-person trainings for students and members of the public through programs such as Skype a Scientist and Lunch with a Scientist. I also continued my efforts engaging and educating citizen scientists, actively connecting with volunteers through social media and in person. To enhance the accessibility of these experiences, I translated our online citizen science platforms into multiple languages, importantly, those spoken in the countries where our data were collected in order to support local engagement in scientific research. Overall, I have been able to reach a very wide audience: over 100,000 volunteers participated during the three years of this fellowship. The key benefit of creating accessible, online material is that there are no barriers to entry: people of varying abilities from diverse geographic and socioeconomic backgrounds are able to participate in real, on-going research and conservation.

Lastly, I have been involved in mentoring five graduate and one undergraduate student in the US and abroad, all of whom all been women and/or minorities. I have contributed to five Women in STEM platforms and performed over a dozen acts of outreach (lecturing at universities, speaking for podcasts and articles, creating online multimedia) on my journey as a woman in science.
